title: Dev Toolbox
summary: A mobile-first, self-hosted developer environment built to make real software development possible on the go — with context, planning, editing, and reasoning all in one place.
problem: There were very few reliable ways to develop software on mobile, and existing tools made the workflow feel fragmented, unpredictable, and detached from real project context. I wanted something calmer, clearer, and closer to the way I actually think.
context: Dev Toolbox began as a response to friction I felt personally: coding on the go wasn't feasible, and switching tools constantly created cognitive drift. My strengths in systems thinking and restorative problem-solving pushed me toward a unified workspace — something self-hosted, adaptable, and designed so that reasoning stayed visible rather than buried.
solution: I designed and built a self-hosted, mobile-first developer environment focused on reducing context switching and preserving clarity. Starting with core essentials — editing, logs, and navigation — the system evolved through real usage to support planning, version control, and explainable reasoning.
keyDecisions: Optimized for mobile-first development instead of desktop parity
Consolidated editing, planning, logs, and context to reduce cognitive switching
Favored structured workflows (sessions, sprints, work items) over ad-hoc flexibility
Chose a self-hosted architecture to preserve control, extensibility, and data ownership
impact: Dev Toolbox made sustained mobile development practical by reducing cognitive load and restoring predictable, focused workflows aligned with how developers reason about their work.
tradeoffs: Dev Toolbox intentionally prioritizes mobile-first workflows rather than full desktop parity. This meant leaving out some advanced editing and visualization features in favor of predictability, low cognitive load, and real usability on smaller screens.

The system was designed primarily for solo and small-team use. Multi-user collaboration features were deferred in favor of strengthening core planning, session logging, and context preservation workflows.

Dev Toolbox favors structured concepts like sessions, sprints, and work items over open-ended flexibility. While this reduces customization, it reinforces clarity, traceability, and explainability in day-to-day work.

Choosing a self-hosted architecture increased setup complexity but preserved data ownership, extensibility, and long-term control — priorities that aligned with the project’s goals even at the cost of onboarding friction.
innovations: Mobile-optimized code block selector for navigating and manipulating structured code
Integrated, always-visible structured logs and console output
Self-hosted GitHub integration for commits, diffs, and repository insights
Unified project planner with sprints, sessions, and context surfaces
AI context packet downloader for explainable, project-aware reasoning

bullets: Frontend: React & TypeScript single-page app bundled with Vite.
Backend & data: Supabase (PostgreSQL + auth) with row-level security and group_id-scoped tables for sprints, sessions, work items, and events.
Infrastructure: Deployed via Cloudflare Pages and Tunnels for secure access to local services.
Developer workflow: GitHub for version control, structured logs for sessions/events, and AI context packets that bundle code, schema, and history for explainable reasoning.

title: Finance Tools / Simplicity
summary: A budgeting and financial-tracking system designed for calm visibility and confident day-to-day money decisions.
problem: Most budgeting tools generate noise instead of clarity. They surface too much, too little, or the wrong information at the wrong moment — creating stress rather than restoring confidence.
context: Simplicity was built to support real financial behavior: recurring bills, flexible spending, shifting obligations, and daily decisions. My adaptive approach to systems and focus on reducing cognitive load shaped the entire flow — designed to meet people where they are, not force them into a rigid model.
solution: I designed and built a mobile-first budgeting system focused on calm visibility rather than exhaustive reporting. The product highlights what matters most in the moment — upcoming obligations, category health, and patterns — while keeping the data honest and predictable over time.
keyDecisions: Designed for frequent, lightweight mobile check-ins
Made category health and headroom immediately visible
Favored predictable, revisitable flows over complex interactions
impact: Simplicity helps users make more confident day-to-day financial decisions by reducing cognitive load and focusing attention on what actually needs action.
innovations: A calm, mobile-first budgeting interface focused on clarity rather than noise
Daily and monthly workflows built around real financial behavior instead of abstract categories
A predictable, honest model for obligations, category health, and recurring patterns
A review flow that keeps new transactions organized without overwhelming the user

bullets: Frontend: React & TypeScript with a mobile-first layout and adaptive card system.
Backend & data: Supabase with Postgres RLS enforcing group_id-based data isolation.
Infrastructure: Uses Supabase Auth for multi-user support and Cloudflare tunneling for local testing.
Developer workflow: Built alongside Dev Toolbox to share schema introspection, session, and documentation tools.

title: Transportation Scheduling Workflow (GAS)
summary: Unified schedules, requests, and driver assignments into a single workflow — reducing data issues, schedule conflicts, and dropped handoffs.
problem: Transportation coordination was affected by messy workflows: schedules, updates, and communication were spread across emails, spreadsheets, and verbal handoffs.
This led to poor data, schedule issues, and communication gaps — and created daily friction and avoidable rework.
The outcome was predictable: details fell through the cracks and dropped balls became a recurring risk.
solution: Introduced a single, clear scheduling workflow with defined steps and one consistent place for schedule data and updates.
Unified vehicle schedules, driver assignments, and departmental requests into a shared system so updates stayed reliable and visible.
Centralized all transportation-related costs in the same workflow, enabling consistent tracking and downstream reporting.
Reduced manual coordination by making the workflow easier to follow and harder to misunderstand.
keyDecisions: Treat schedule issues as workflow and data integrity problems, not individual mistakes.
Consolidated where information lives so everyone works from the same truth.
Favor a repeatable process over informal workarounds to prevent dropped handoffs.
impact: More complete and reliable schedule data
Reduced reconciliation effort and billing errors by keeping scheduling and cost data in a single, reliable workflow.
Fewer scheduling conflicts and missed assignments
Fewer communication gaps and fewer dropped balls
Less day-to-day friction and fewer interruptions
tradeoffs: Required behavior change and more consistent update discipline.
Reduced informal workarounds in favor of a shared process everyone could follow.

title: Aurora
summary: A conceptual approach to building software through conversation, centered on intent, understanding, and transparent results.
problem: Software creation today is fragmented across documents, tools, and communication channels, making it difficult to maintain clarity, shared understanding, and a coherent path from intention to result.
context: Aurora emerged from years of operational work and independent software development, shaped by questions around clarity, communication, and how people naturally express intent. My connectedness and restorative instincts made the friction especially visible — systems drifted, reasoning wasn’t transparent, and meaning often became diluted across layers.
solution: Aurora explores a conversational workflow where people express what they want, the system reflects its understanding, and results evolve through shared reasoning. This mirrors how people naturally collaborate — through dialogue, refinement, and relational clarity — without revealing any internal mechanisms or technical structures.
innovations: A conceptual approach to software shaped through conversation instead of traditional development steps
A workflow centered on intent → understanding → result, emphasizing clarity and shared reasoning
An exploration of explainability as a foundational property of software creation
A vision for more natural, transparent human–AI collaboration in shaping digital systems
impact: Aurora offers a direction for future tools that prioritize clarity, explainability, and human-centered interaction with complex systems. It reframes how software could be shaped — focusing on meaning, reasoning, and alignment rather than layers of translation.

bullets: Prototype engine implemented in Python for kernel logic and structured logging.
Uses Supabase (Postgres) as the underlying data and provenance store.
Focus on explainability, context bundling, and provenance-aware state management.
Conceptually extends Dev Toolbox and Simplicity into a unified conversational system design.
